SystemOutput:
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Mr. Brian is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for congestive heart failure and hypertension, who presents today for follow-up of his chronic problems. The patient reports feeling out of sorts, fatigued, and lightheaded for the past five weeks. He attributes this to increased activity around the house and possible seasonal changes. He also reports occasional bloating and shortness of breath during exertion. The patient admits to struggling with his diet due to recent home renovations, which led to eating out more frequently. He denies fever, chills, chest pain, and significant cough.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Positive fatigue and lightheadedness. No fever or chills.
• Cardiovascular: No chest pain. Positive bloating.
• Respiratory: Positive shortness of breath during exertion. Mild cough.
• Gastrointestinal: No nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Constitutional: Vital signs within normal limits.
• Neck: Jugular venous distention to 8 cm.
• Cardiovascular: 3/6 systolic ejection murmur.
• Respiratory: Fine crackles at lung bases bilaterally.
• Extremities: 1+ pitting edema in lower extremities.

RESULTS

Chest X-ray: Fluid in lungs.
Echocardiogram (4 months ago): Ejection fraction at 45%, mitral regurgitation.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Congestive Heart Failure:
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient is retaining fluid, as evidenced by physical exam findings and chest X-ray.
   • Medical Treatment: Increase Lasix to 80 mg once a day. Patient to weigh themselves daily and report any weight gain or worsening symptoms.
   • Additional Testing: Order a new echocardiogram.

2. Hypertension:
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient's blood pressure is well-managed at this time.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue lisinopril 20 mg daily. Patient to monitor blood pressure at home and report any elevations through the patient portal.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CC:

Right knee pain.

HPI:

Ms. Thompson is a 43-year-old female who presents today for an evaluation of right knee pain. She reports that she was trying to change a light bulb on a ladder yesterday when she stumbled and twisted her knee while trying to catch her fall. She has been applying ice and taking ibuprofen, but it does not seem to help much. She has a history of atrial fibrillation and takes digoxin. She has a past surgical history of a rhinoplasty. She denies any allergies.

EXAM:

Examination of the right knee shows tenderness over the medial portion of the knee, over the medial meniscus area. Pain is elicited with flexion and valgus stress. Normal sensation is present in the lower extremity. No calf pain is reported.

RESULTS:

X-rays of the left knee obtained on today's visit show no fractures or dislocations. There is a small amount of fluid present, but overall alignment is normal.

IMPRESSION:

Acute medial meniscus sprain or strain of the right knee.

PLAN:

At this point, I discussed the diagnosis and treatment options with the patient. I have recommended we place her in a knee brace and provide her with crutches for temporary use. She will follow up in 1 week for reevaluation, and if not improved, we will consider an MRI. I will prescribe Motrin 800 mg, #28 (twenty-eight) to take every 6 hours with food as needed for pain.

All questions were answered.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Back pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Logan is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for diabetes type 2, hypertension, osteoarthritis, who presents today with back pain.

The patient states he was helping his daughter with heavy equipment and lifted some boxes too quickly, which were too heavy. This happened on Saturday morning, and he felt a pop in his lower back. He had to lie down for about an hour before the pain was relieved, and it has been stiff ever since. He reports taking Tylenol, ibuprofen, and using icy heat, which did not provide significant relief. He experienced tingling in his toes on his right foot until Sunday afternoon.

Regarding his diabetes, he admits to having a sweet tooth and not having the best diet recently. He plans to improve his eating habits. He is taking his medication for hypertension but has not been consistent with monitoring his blood pressure readings at home.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Denies weight loss. Denies fever, chills, nausea, or vomiting.
• Musculoskeletal: Endorses back pain. Denies any other joint pain.
• Neurological: Endorses tingling in toes on the right foot, which resolved.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Cardiovascular: Grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur, stable.
• Musculoskeletal: Examination of his back reveals pain to palpation at the lumbar spine. Decreased range of motion with flexion and extension. Negative straight leg raise.

Results:

X-ray lumbar spine, ordered and obtained in the office today, is unremarkable with good bony alignment.

Hemoglobin A1c is elevated at 8.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Logan is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for diabetes type 2, hypertension, osteoarthritis, who presents today with back pain.

Acute lumbar strain.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient reports feeling a 'pop' and immediate pain while lifting heavy boxes. He has tried Tylenol and ibuprofen without significant relief.
• Additional Testing: None at this time.
• Medical Treatment: Initiate meloxicam 15 mg once daily. Continue icing the area and avoiding strenuous activity.
• Specialist Referrals: Refer to physical therapy for strengthening exercises.

Diabetes type 2.
• Medical Reasoning: His recent hemoglobin A1c was 8, indicating suboptimal control.
• Additional Testing: Repeat hemoglobin A1c in 6 months.
• Medical Treatment: Increase metformin to 1000 mg twice daily.

Hypertension.
• Medical Reasoning: Blood pressure readings have been running on the high side.
• Additional Testing: None at this time.
• Medical Treatment: Increase lisinopril from 10 mg to 20 mg daily.

Osteoarthritis.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient is managing his knee osteoarthritis well and no further workup is needed at this time.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow-up in 2 weeks.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Annual exam and follow-up of chronic problems.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ralph is a 62-year-old male with a past medical history significant for depression, hypertension, and prior lobectomy. He presents for his annual exam. The patient reports doing relatively well, with some stress from moving his daughter to college. He has been experiencing nasal congestion due to pollen.

Regarding his depression, he has been taking Prozac and reports no recent incidents. He is managing his hypertension with Norvasc, but admits to occasionally forgetting to take it on weekends. He has a history of lobectomy and reports no significant shortness of breath except during high pollen and humidity.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Ears, Nose, Mouth and Throat: Endorses nasal congestion.
• Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain, reports occasional chest pounding during exercise.
• Respiratory: Shortness of breath with exertion.
• Psychiatric: Endorses depression.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Ears, Nose, Mouth and Throat: Pain to palpation of sinuses.
• Cardiovascular: Slight 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.
• Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally.
• Extremities: No lower extremity edema.

VITALS REVIEWED

• Blood Pressure: 120/80 mmHg.

RESULTS

Electrocardiogram: Normal.
Chest X-ray: Normal, no concerns related to prior lobectomy.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Depression.
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient is doing well on Prozac 20 mg daily.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue Prozac 20 mg daily, refill prescription.
   • Patient Education and Counseling: Encouraged to continue current management strategies.

2. Prior lobectomy.
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient is exercising regularly and has good breathing function.
   • Medical Treatment: No further follow-up with the surgeon is needed.

3. Hypertension.
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient's blood pressure is well-controlled, but admits to occasional noncompliance on weekends.
   • Additional Testing: Order an echocardiogram for the murmur.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue Norvasc as prescribed.
   • Patient Education and Counseling: Encouraged to maintain medication compliance and follow up on test results through the patient portal.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CC:

Right index finger pain.

HPI:

Ms. Brooks is a 48-year-old female who presents today for an evaluation of right index finger pain after a skiing accident over the weekend. She reports that her finger was bent back while skiing over moguls.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS:

Miralax

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:

Constipation, Appendectomy at age 18

EXAM:

Examination of the right index finger shows tenderness over the distal phalanx. No tenderness over the proximal joint or metacarpophalangeal joint. Pain with flexion.

RESULTS:

X-rays of the right index finger obtained on today's visit show no fractures and everything lines up well.

IMPRESSION:

Right index finger contusion.

PLAN:

At this point, I discussed the diagnosis and treatment options with the patient. I recommend an aluminum foam splint and a prescription for Motrin 600 mg every 6 hours for one week. The patient is advised to call and return for a follow-up if the pain does not improve within a week. All questions were answered.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Iron deficiency anemia.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ms. Christina Cooper is a 65-year-old female with a history of iron deficiency anemia since the age of 13. She presents today after being unable to donate blood in December 2019 due to her anemia. She reports fatigue, feverishness, chills, shortness of breath, wheezing, and headaches. She also notes increased anxiety and depression. She had a hysterectomy in 1996 and her last colonoscopy was approximately 5-6 years ago with no significant findings. She denies having a pacemaker, defibrillator, sleep apnea, or using oxygen at night. She drinks alcohol only once or twice a year. She is currently taking ferrous sulfate 25 mg twice daily and over-the-counter vitamin B12.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Endorses fatigue, feverishness, and chills.
• Respiratory: Endorses shortness of breath and wheezing.
• Neurological: Endorses headaches.
• Psychiatric: Endorses increased anxiety and depression.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• General: Normal physical exam without significant findings.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Ms. Christina Cooper is a 65-year-old female with a history of iron deficiency anemia, presenting today for evaluation and management.

Iron deficiency anemia.
• Medical Reasoning: She has been dealing with anemia since the age of 13, with recent blood work showing low hemoglobin, stable hematocrit, normal iron labs, and low ferritin. She is currently taking ferrous sulfate and vitamin B12.
• Additional Testing: We will recheck CBC, iron, ferritin, B12, and folate in 12 weeks after continuing ferrous sulfate with vitamin C found in orange juice.
• Specialist Referrals: We will refer her to a hematologist for further evaluation and management.

Gastrointestinal evaluation.
• Medical Reasoning: To assess for potential sources of anemia or GI bleed, given her history of iron deficiency anemia.
• Additional Testing: We will schedule an upper endoscopy (EGD) and colonoscopy. If these tests are inconclusive, we will consider a capsule endoscopy.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Worsening headaches and incidentally discovered pituitary lesion.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Mr. Bruce Ward is a 52-year-old male who presents to the clinic today for consultation regarding a newly diagnosed pituitary lesion. He was referred by Dr. Henry Howard for possible surgical intervention. Mr. Ward initially presented to his primary care provider on 3/1/21 with worsening headaches over the past few months. His past clinical history is unremarkable.

Workup for worsening headaches was initiated with brain MRI and serology, where the pituitary lesion was incidentally discovered. Pertinent labs and radiology studies were reviewed, including a pituitary hormone profile demonstrating a low TSH and an MRI revealing a pituitary lesion with elevation and compression of the optic chiasm.

The patient reports headaches located behind his eyes, described as a dull nagging ache, with a gradual onset and worsening over the past three months. The headaches are worse in the morning and last a few hours at a time. He denies any other symptoms, including fever, neck stiffness, numbness, or weakness. However, he has recently noticed bumping into door frames.

PAST HISTORY

Medical
Unremarkable.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Occupation: Computer programmer.
Marital status: Married for 25 years.
Alcohol, tobacco, and drug use: None.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

None.

EXAMINATION

The patient is alert, oriented to time, place, and person. Affect is appropriate and speech is fluent. Cranial nerve examination is grossly intact. No focal motor or sensory deficit in the upper or lower extremities. Visual acuity and eye movements are normal. Pupils are equal and reactive. Visual field testing reveals bitemporal hemianopia. Color vision is normal.

ASSESSMENT

Pituitary adenoma with optic chiasmal compression.

PLAN

1. Refer the patient to an eye doctor for a full exam and visual field test to map peripheral vision prior to surgery.
2. Schedule surgery for transsphenoidal approach to excise and decompress the pituitary fossa.
3. Counsel the patient on the risks associated with surgery and anesthesia.
4. Monitor the patient's vision post-surgery for improvement.
5. Encourage the patient to call if any questions arise.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Betty Hill is a 53-year-old female with a past medical history of uterine fibroids, anemia, and gallbladder removal. She presents as a new patient with a referral from the ER for esophagitis. The patient reports having chest pain for four days in early October 2020, which resolved on its own. She has not had any chest pain since then. The pain was located in the center of her chest, behind her breastbone, and was sharp in nature. The patient experienced difficulty swallowing during the episode, which has also resolved. She denies any recent abdominal pain and reports normal bowel movements. She has been trying to lose weight and was going through a stressful job transition at the time of the chest pain episode.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

Abdomen
• Examination of Abdomen: Mild tenderness to light palpation in the upper abdominal quadrants. No pain or tenderness in the lower abdomen.

RESULTS

ER visit in October 2020: EKG and blood tests were normal.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

The patient is a 53-year-old female who presents with a history of chest pain and difficulty swallowing in October 2020. The chest pain has resolved, and the patient has not experienced any additional episodes since then. Possible etiologies include GERD, dyspepsia, esophagitis, musculoskeletal etiologies, and anxiety. The patient's job transition stress may have contributed to an anxiety attack, which could have caused or exacerbated her symptoms.

The patient was offered the option of an EGD or upper endoscopy to evaluate her esophagus and stomach for esophagitis. However, given the resolution of her symptoms and the time elapsed since the episode, the patient elected to self-monitor her symptoms and will call with any reoccurrence or change. She will follow up as needed for any other GI complaints.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Concerns related to Smith-Magenis Syndrome.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Katherine is a 22-month-old female with a history of Smith-Magenis Syndrome, presenting today for evaluation of her kidneys and urinary tract. She has a twin sister who is healthy and a 9-year-old brother with autism. Katherine has had issues with feeding, temperature regulation, and developmental delays. She is currently in feeding therapy, occupational therapy, physical therapy, and will soon start speech therapy. She has seen multiple specialists, including a GI doctor, dietician, allergist, neurologist, orthopedic, ophthalmologist, and audiologist. The patient's mother reports that Katherine has 8-10 wet diapers per day and drinks a combination of pea protein milk, water, and diluted juice.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: No fever, chills, or weight loss.
• Ears, Nose, Mouth, and Throat: No recent infections or issues.
• Cardiovascular: No known issues.
• Respiratory: No cough, shortness of breath.
• Gastrointestinal: History of reflux, currently managed.
• Genitourinary: No known issues.
• Musculoskeletal: Developmental delays, mild hypotonia in lower extremities.
• Neurological: Developmental delays, history of Smith-Magenis Syndrome.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• General: Well-nourished female, slightly fussy when examined.
• Eyes: Small appearing.
• Extremities: Mild hypotonia of the lower extremities and arms.
• Genitalia: Normal external female genitalia.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Katherine is a 22-month-old female with a history of Smith-Magenis Syndrome. Congenital anomalies of the kidney and urinary tract have been reported in the literature for this syndrome.

• Kidney Ultrasound: We will obtain a screening of the kidneys by ultrasound today. If there are abnormalities on the kidney ultrasound, we will determine next steps and future follow-up.

• Follow-up: The family lives in Dallas, Georgia, so her follow-up should be at the town center location if needed.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right wrist pain and swelling.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Diana is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of right wrist pain and swelling. The onset of her pain began when she slipped while carrying laundry down the stairs and tried to catch herself with her right arm. The patient reports severe pain, rated 9 out of 10. She has been icing her wrist, using an ACE wrap, and taking ibuprofen, which provided minimal relief. The patient denies any previous injuries to her right arm.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Positive right wrist pain and swelling.
Neurological: Mild tingling in fingers, no numbness.

VITALS

BP: 140/70
HR: 80 bpm
RR: 20
Temp: 97.2°F
SPO2: Not provided.

PHYSICAL EXAM

CV: No carotid bruit, no thyromegaly, no adenopathy.
Pulmonary: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Extremities: No lower leg edema, palpable pulses.
MSK: Right wrist with obvious swelling, ecchymosis, and tenderness on palpation. Pain on flexion, extension, radial deviation, and ulnar deviation. Limited ability to make a fist. Bony crepitus present.

RESULTS

X-ray of the right wrist reveals a Colles' fracture with extra-articular involvement and ulnar styloid fracture.

ASSESSMENT

Right wrist Colles' fracture.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with the patient in regards to her current symptoms. I have explained to her that her symptoms are consistent with a Colles' fracture. I have recommended conservative treatment initially with a wrist brace. The patient will be scheduled for surgery as soon as possible. Post-surgery, the patient will be in a brace for six weeks and will begin physical therapy. The patient will be prescribed 50 mg of Ultram every six hours for pain management. A follow-up appointment will be scheduled in one month to assess the patient's progress and discuss her upcoming vacation plans.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient is advised to follow the prescribed treatment plan and attend all scheduled appointments. If pain worsens or new symptoms arise, the patient should contact the office immediately.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right knee pain.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Hypertension, on 20 mg Lisinopril.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient reports working on his property when the injury occurred.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies fever, chest pain, and shortness of breath.
Musculoskeletal: Reports right knee pain and swelling.

VITALS

Blood pressure: 150/70 mmHg
Heart rate: Not provided
Respiration: Not provided
No fever.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Respiratory
- Assessment of Respiratory Effort: Normal respiratory effort. Lungs clear bilaterally.

Cardiovascular
- Examination: Grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.
- Auscultation of Heart: Regular rate and rhythm. No gallops or rubs.

Musculoskeletal
- Examination: Right knee pain with flexion and extension. Pain to palpation of the medial aspect of the right knee. Edema around the knee and effusion present.

RESULTS

X-rays of the right knee were obtained and reviewed. These reveal no fractures or bony abnormalities.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Right knee MCL strain.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient reports slipping and falling, resulting in knee pain and swelling.
- Medical Treatment: Prescribe ibuprofen 800 mg twice daily for pain and inflammation. Provide a knee brace for support and recommend icing the knee for 20 minutes, 3-4 times daily.
- Patient Education and Counseling: Advise the patient to elevate and rest the leg, and avoid strenuous activities for a couple of weeks.

2. Hypertension.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient's blood pressure was elevated at 150/70 mmHg during the visit.
- Medical Treatment: Continue 20 mg Lisinopril.
- Patient Education and Counseling: Refer the patient to a nutritionist to help improve diet and reduce sodium intake.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up as needed.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left shoulder pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Wayne is a pleasant male patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of left shoulder pain. The onset of his pain began 3 weeks ago, without any improvement. He denies any specific injury; however, he has been renovating his basement and suspects it might be related. The patient states he is very active and has experienced occasional aches and pains before that usually resolve with Tylenol.

The patient reports significant pain with reaching, lifting, and overhead activities. The pain is constant and worsens when pressure is applied. He states the pain is primarily located in the left shoulder and denies it radiates down into the left arm. The patient also reports difficulty sleeping secondary to the pain. He denies any numbness or tingling in his left arm or fingers. He has been taking Tylenol for pain, which provides partial relief.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports left shoulder pain. Neurological: Denies numbness or tingling.

VITALS

All vital signs are within the normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

MSK: Examination of the left shoulder: Limited active and passive ROM. Tenderness over the greater tuberosity of the humerus. No tenderness at the sternoclavicular or AC joints. Good hand grip. Neurovascularly intact distally. Capillary refill is less than 3 seconds. Sensation is intact to light touch distally.

RESULTS

X-rays of the left shoulder were obtained and reviewed today. These are normal and reveal no fracture or bony abnormalities.

ASSESSMENT

Left shoulder pain, likely rotator cuff tendinopathy.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with him regarding his current symptoms. I have explained that his x-rays did not reveal any signs of a fracture. I have recommended that we obtain an MRI of the left shoulder to evaluate for possible rotator cuff tendinopathy. The patient was provided with a referral to formal physical therapy. He will engage in a 6-to-8-week course in order to strengthen his left shoulder. I have also advised him to take Tylenol as needed for pain. If his symptoms do not improve, we may consider a steroid injection to the left shoulder.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up with me once the MRI results are available for review and further discussion.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left knee pain and instability.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Andrea is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of left knee pain and instability. The patient reports that her left knee occasionally gives out while walking, causing her to nearly fall. This occurs less than once a day and resolves quickly. She has not experienced any popping sensation or significant injury to the knee. The patient denies taking any medications for pain, as the issue does not last long. She is concerned about participating in line dancing during an upcoming trip due to her knee instability.

MEDICATIONS

The patient is currently taking Farxiga, Amlodipine, Lisinopril, Hydrochlorothiazide, and Metformin.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports left knee pain and instability. Denies right knee pain.

Cardiovascular: Reports controlled blood pressure.

Endocrine: Reports slightly elevated morning blood sugars.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vital Signs: Temperature 98.2, Pulse 72, Respirations 16, Blood Pressure 122/70.

Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, 2/6 systolic ejection murmur at the left base.

Pulmonary: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.

MSK: Examination of the left knee: No ecchymosis, edema, or effusion. No pain to palpation. Full range of motion. Negative varus and valgus test.

RESULTS

Left knee x-ray: No evidence of fracture or bony abnormality.

ASSESSMENT

1. Left knee pain and instability, likely due to arthritis.
2. Hypertension.
3. Diabetes mellitus.

PLAN

1. For the left knee pain and instability, prescribe meloxicam 15 mg daily and consider initiating physical therapy to strengthen the surrounding muscles.
2. Continue Lisinopril 20 mg daily for hypertension and order an echocardiogram to evaluate the heart murmur.
3. Order a hemoglobin A1c and lipid panel to assess diabetes management and potential adjustments to Metformin dosage.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Cough and sore throat.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient is a 53-year-old female with a recent diagnosis of stage three non-small cell lung cancer. She is currently undergoing neo-adjuvant chemotherapy. Biopsy of a 4.4 cm left upper lobe nodule was positive for adenocarcinoma. Molecular testing is pending.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient reports having a good support system from family, friends, and nursing staff.

MEDICATIONS

Patient is currently on cisplatin and etoposide chemotherapy.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Reports fatigue.
Respiratory: Reports a dry cough and sore throat. Denies shortness of breath.
Gastrointestinal: Denies difficulty swallowing or feeling of food getting stuck.

VITALS

Oxygen saturation: Within normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Head and Neck
- Examination: No cervical or supraclavicular lymphadenopathy.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs.

Respiratory
- Auscultation of Lungs: Crackles bilaterally.

Skin
- Examination: Erythema on the anterior left side of the chest, likely related to radiation.

Lower Extremities
- Examination: No edema.

RESULTS

Chest X-ray: Mild radiation pneumonitis.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Non-small cell lung cancer.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient is currently undergoing chemotherapy with cisplatin and etoposide and radiation therapy.
- Medical Treatment: Continue with the current chemotherapy regimen and radiation dose of 45 Gy. Repeat imaging after completion to assess tumor response and potential for surgical resection.

2. Radiation pneumonitis.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient has mild radiation pneumonitis, likely causing her cough and contributing to her sore throat.
- Medical Treatment: Prescribe low-dose prednisone (40 mg daily for 5 days) to reduce inflammation and improve symptoms.

3. Sore throat and painful swallowing.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient has inflammation in her esophagus likely related to radiation therapy.
- Medical Treatment: Prescribe lidocaine swish and swallow four times a day to help with pain relief and improve swallowing.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Low immunoglobulin A level.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient reports recent international travel to Zambia. Family owns a donut shop.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient has been recently diagnosed with type 2 diabetes and is on metformin.

FAMILY HISTORY

No known family history of immune deficiencies.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: No fever.
Respiratory: Lungs clear, no wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs.
Gastrointestinal: Abdomen soft, non-tender.

VITALS

All vitals within normal range.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs.

Respiratory
- Auscultation of Lungs: Clear, no wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.

Gastrointestinal
- Examination: Soft, non-tender abdomen.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Low immunoglobulin A level.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient's lab work is consistent with an IgA deficiency. However, the patient does not report frequent infections or other symptoms typically associated with this deficiency.
- Patient Education and Counseling: The nature of the diagnosis was discussed with the patient. They were advised to watch for infections that do not resolve or any changes in their abdominal tract. They were also informed to notify healthcare providers of their IgA deficiency if they ever need blood products.
- Medical Treatment: Additional blood work will be ordered to check for other immunodeficiencies. The patient will be scheduled for a follow-up appointment to review the results of the additional blood work.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right elbow pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Lawrence is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of right elbow pain. The patient has been experiencing right elbow pain for approximately 4 days. He has been doing a lot of pottery recently and believes this may have caused the pain. The pain is localized to the inside of his elbow and can radiate slightly into his forearm. He denies any trauma or previous injury to the elbow. The pain is rated as 6/10 and has been affecting his sleep and daily activities. He has tried ibuprofen with minimal relief.

SOCIAL HISTORY

The patient has been engaging in pottery during the pandemic.

MEDICATIONS

The patient reports that he has been taking ibuprofen for pain relief.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports right elbow pain.

PHYSICAL EXAM

CV: Pulses are equal in all extremities.
NEURO: Sensation is normal to light touch distally.
MSK: 
Examination of the right elbow: Pain to palpation along the medial aspect. No pain with supination. Pain with pronation. Pain with resistance against flexion of the left wrist.

RESULTS

X-ray images of the right elbow were obtained and reviewed in the office today. These reveal no evidence of fracture or bony misalignment.

ASSESSMENT

Right medial epicondylitis.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, we discussed the diagnosis of medial epicondylitis. The patient is advised to rest the elbow and wear a sling while awake. He is instructed to apply ice to the elbow for 20 minutes, three times a day, and take ibuprofen 600 mg q.6 h. with food for a full week. The patient is advised to avoid pottery work for the next couple of weeks. A follow-up appointment is scheduled for one week to assess progress.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Emergency department follow up after a fall and chest pain.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports history of hypertension and recent dietary indiscretion.

MEDICATIONS

Patient reports taking Bumex 2 mg once daily, Cozaar 100 mg daily, and Norvasc 5 mg once daily, but admits to occasional missed doses.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies sleep disturbance.
Cardiovascular: Reports occasional chest pain, thought to be heartburn.
Respiratory: Reports shortness of breath during recent episode.
Genitourinary: No issues reported.

VITALS

Blood Pressure: 128/72 mmHg
Temperature: 98.7 degrees F
Heart Rate: 72 bpm
Oxygen Saturation: 96%

PHYSICAL EXAM

Neck
- General Examination: No jugular venous distention.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Stable 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.

Respiratory
- Auscultation of Lungs: Clear bilaterally.

Musculoskeletal
- Examination: Trace lower extremity edema.

RESULTS

Echocardiogram reveals a preserved ejection fraction of 55%, abnormal diastolic filling, and mild-to-moderate mitral regurgitation.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Congestive heart failure.
- Medical Reasoning: This appears to have been caused by dietary indiscretion and uncontrolled hypertension.
- Patient Education and Counseling: Encouraged the patient to continue making dietary modifications, including limiting sodium intake. Referral placed for consult with a nutritionist for education and recommendations regarding diet.
- Medical Treatment: Continue with Bumex 2 mg once daily.

2. Hypertension.
- Medical Reasoning: This has been poorly controlled due to inconsistent compliance with medication and dietary indiscretion.
- Patient Education and Counseling: Discussed the importance of taking medications consistently and monitoring diet.
- Medical Treatment: Continue on Cozaar 100 mg daily and Norvasc 5 mg once daily. Renal artery ultrasound ordered to rule out any issues such as renal artery stenosis.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up in 3 months.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right-sided abdominal pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Russell is a patient who presents with sharp pain on the right side of his abdomen below his ribs for the last several days. The pain radiates to his lower abdomen and into his groin. The pain is intermittent and severe when it occurs. He reports burning sensation during urination and dark-colored urine. He has taken Tylenol for pain with minimal relief. The patient has a history of kidney stones and a family history of kidney stones (father). His primary care physician ordered a CT scan, which revealed a kidney stone, and referred him to a urologist.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Gastrointestinal: Reports nausea but no vomiting.
Genitourinary: Reports burning sensation during urination and dark-colored urine.

VITALS

Not provided.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Abdomen: No tenderness to palpation, no rebound or guarding, no peritoneal signs.
CVA: Positive tenderness on the right flank.

RESULTS

CT scan of the abdomen revealed a 0.5 cm stone located in the proximal right ureter. No evidence of hydronephrosis.

ASSESSMENT

Acute nephrolithiasis (kidney stone).

PLAN

1. Encourage increased fluid intake to facilitate urination and stone passage.
2. Prescribe oxycodone 5 mg every 6 to 8 hours as needed for pain. Patient may continue to take Tylenol for additional pain relief.
3. Provide a strainer for the patient to use when urinating to catch the stone for further analysis.
4. Order a basic metabolic panel (BMP), urinalysis, and urine culture to evaluate for any signs of infection.
5. Schedule a follow-up appointment in 1 to 2 weeks to assess progress. If symptoms persist, discuss further treatment options such as lithotripsy or ureteroscopy.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient is advised to contact the doctor if symptoms worsen or if there are any concerns.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Non-healing right foot ulcer.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Nicholas is a patient with a history of diabetes and diabetic neuropathy who presents today for evaluation of a non-healing right foot ulcer. He reports having the ulcer for approximately 6 weeks, which he first noticed after wearing a tight pair of shoes. The ulcer initially presented as a blister with stinging pain, but has since worsened with a foul smell, yellow drainage, and blackened tissue around the wound. The patient has been on antibiotics for 6 days, with some improvement in symptoms, but he has also developed cramping in his calf muscle and a red streak along his calf. He has experienced a fever of 99.7°F and chills. His blood sugars have been trending higher than normal, with a recent A1c of 6.7.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports history of diabetes and diabetic neuropathy.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient reports enjoying hiking with his wife and recently trying new trails.

MEDICATIONS

Patient reports taking antibiotics for the foot ulcer.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Reports fever and chills.
Cardiovascular: No chest pain.
Respiratory: Reports coughing and shortness of breath.
Skin: Patient reports non-healing right foot ulcer.
Neurological: No headaches or numbness/tingling in feet.

VITALS

Slight fever.
Blood pressure: Not provided
Heart rate: Not provided

PHYSICAL EXAM

CV: Not provided
RESPIRATORY: Not provided
NECK: Not provided
MSK: Examination of the right foot reveals a 2 x 2 cm necrotic wound on the heel with sloughing tissue, cellulitis, and erythemia. No bony exposure. Vascular exam shows bilateral palpable femoral and popliteal pulses, but no palpable dorsalis pedis or posterior tibial pulses (present via Doppler). No pain upon pressing the affected area of the wound.

ASSESSMENT

1. Non-healing diabetic foot ulcer, right foot
2. Diabetes with recent elevated blood sugars
3. Possible cellulitis

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination findings today, I have discussed the current symptoms and plan with the patient. We will order a test to check blood supply for the wound. I will perform a debridement today in the office and obtain a culture to guide antibiotic therapy. The patient will continue his current antibiotic course, with potential changes based on culture results. We will closely monitor the redness and swelling in his calf. A follow-up appointment is scheduled in 7 days. The patient is advised to follow up with his endocrinologist for diabetes management and to maintain a hemoglobin A1c below 7.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Tick bite on right knee with associated pain and erythema.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Patient reports spending time outdoors and recently going hunting. He noticed a tick bite on his right knee over a week ago, which has been causing burning pain and annoyance. He denies fever, chills, and joint pain in other areas. He has not been previously diagnosed with Lyme disease.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Hypertension: Controlled with lisinopril 20 mg daily.
Diabetes: Controlled with metformin 1000 mg twice daily.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies fever, chills, and body aches. Reports headache and general malaise since tick bite.
Respiratory: Denies cough or shortness of breath.
Musculoskeletal: Denies joint pain other than typical arthritic pain.

VITALS

Blood pressure: 122/70 mmHg
Heart rate: 67 bpm
Respiration: Not reported
Temperature: 98.4°F

PHYSICAL EXAM

Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs, gallops, or rubs.
Respiratory: Clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Musculoskeletal: Full range of motion in right knee. Pain to palpation of right anterior knee. Erythema, edema, and area of fluctuance over right patella.
Skin: Bull's-eye rash over right knee.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Suspected Lyme disease due to tick bite and bull's-eye rash.
- Medical Treatment: Start doxycycline 100 mg twice daily for 3 weeks.
- Diagnostic Testing: Order Lyme titer and Western blot to confirm diagnosis.

2. Hypertension: Well-controlled with lisinopril 20 mg daily.
- Continue current medication.
- Order lipid panel to assess cholesterol levels.

3. Diabetes: Well-controlled with metformin 1000 mg twice daily.
- Continue current medication.
- Order hemoglobin A1c to assess long-term blood sugar control.
- Order basic metabolic panel to monitor kidney function.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up as needed or if symptoms worsen.
